content:
Suppose fff is a morphism in a 2-category (or just a functor, or just an object of a non-symmetric monoidal category). What is a good pair of dual-looking notations for the left and right adjoints (duals) of fff, if they exist?

I've recently been writing f∗f^*f∗ for the left adjoint and f∗f_*f∗​ for the right adjoint, so that f∗⊣f⊣f∗f^* \dashv f \dashv f_*f∗⊣f⊣f∗​, but this could be confusing since often X∗X^*X∗ just means "the" dual in a symmetric monoidal category, and in many contexts (e.g. geometric morphisms) we have f∗⊣f∗f^* \dashv f_*f∗⊣f∗​ without an fff in the middle.

I don't know if you want a pre-existing notation, or if you're considering inventing a new one. So, I don't know what already exists - but how about f⊢⊣f⊣f⊣f^\vdash \dashv f \dashv f ^\dashvf⊢⊣f⊣f⊣? The left adjoint has the vertical bar on the left, and the right adjoint has the vertical bar on the right.

I don't think there's an existing "standard" notation, or at least if there is it's not standard enough for me to have heard about it. But I'd be interested both in notations that have been used already and proposals for new ones.

I can see f⊣f^{\dashv}f⊣ for the right adjoint, but I don't really like f⊢f^{\vdash}f⊢ for the left adjoint, because ⊢\vdash⊢ is hardly ever used to denote adjunctions, and has other meanings such as a logical turnstile. Would ⊣f{}^{\dashv}f⊣f be too ugly?

Would ⊣f{}^{\dashv}f ⊣f be too ugly?

It might be awkward if you're composing adjoints, because it may not be clear to which morphism the turnstile is associated without parentheses.
Another disadvantage of f∗⊣f∗f^* \dashv f_*f∗⊣f∗​ is that some people have the opposite convention (e.g. in at least some of the literature on proarrow equipments).
(I don't have a suggestion, though; I'd also be interested in finding better notation.)
What about f!⊣f⊣f!f^! \dashv f \dashv f_!f!⊣f⊣f!​?
For what it's worth, as a beginner to this stuff, I find moving notation up and down to indicate left/right very hard to remember. I'm sure this comes with practice, but I find it a bit arbitrary.
I have used fLf^LfL and fRf^RfR (just for my own notes).
In a [[pregroup grammar]] one usually uses xlx^lxl and xrx^rxr instead.
Anything involving a subscript feels wrong to me because of the contravariance.

Nathanael Arkor said:

Another disadvantage of f∗⊣f∗f^* \dashv f_*f∗⊣f∗​ is that some people have the opposite convention (e.g. in at least some of the literature on proarrow equipments).

This very upsetting.

Matteo Capucci (he/him) said:

What about f!⊣f⊣f!f^! \dashv f \dashv f_!f!⊣f⊣f!​?

I'd have expected f!f_!f!​ to be the left adjoint...
Ah, yes, I think I have seen xlx^lxl and xrx^rxr. And I think I have seen fLf^LfL and fRf^RfR before too, perhaps in Lurie's work on [[fully dualizable objects]] in (∞,n)(\infty,n)(∞,n)-categories?

Hmm, I just glanced back at Lurie's paper and didn't see it, but I feel like I have seen this notation somewhere for 2-categories with all adjoints, ⋯⊣fLL⊣fL⊣f⊣fR⊣fRR⊣…\dots \dashv f^{LL} \dashv f^L \dashv f \dashv f^R \dashv f^{RR} \dashv \dots ⋯⊣fLL⊣fL⊣f⊣fR⊣fRR⊣….
And it's a good point that subscripts tend to denote covariant operations and superscripts contravariant ones, and passage to both left and right adjoints is contravariant.
That's the context in which I was using this notation so I would have believed I got it from Lurie's paper, if you hadn't said it's not in there.
I could have missed it.

In the notation of Fausk-Hu-May Isomorphisms between left and right adjoints, we have f∗⊣f∗f^* \dashv f_*f∗⊣f∗​ and f!⊣f∗f_! \dashv f^*f!​⊣f∗, while sometimes f∗=f!f_* = f_!f∗​=f!​ and other times f∗=f!f^* = f^!f∗=f!. So if we identified fff itself with f∗f_*f∗​, we could have f∗⊣f⊣f!f^* \dashv f \dashv f^!f∗⊣f⊣f!.

On the other hand, Chaitanya pointed out to me that upper and lower stars and shrieks are all usually used for an induced action on presheaves/modules/etc., so it would be confusing to also use them for maps of domains. For instance, if f:A→Bf:A\to Bf:A→B is a functor in Cat\rm CatCat, then f∗f^*f∗ often denotes the induced precomposition functor PB→PAPB \to PAPB→PA on presheaves, so we wouldn't want to also use it for a left adjoint functor B→AB\to AB→A.
Another symbol that could be used for one or the other is f†f^\daggerf†. But I'm not sure which it would be, or what the other one would be. Maybe f§⊣f⊣f†f^\S \dashv f \dashv f^\daggerf§⊣f⊣f†?
f♭⊣f⊣f♯f^\flat \dashv f \dashv f^\sharpf♭⊣f⊣f♯?

Tempting! But I'm doing this in the context of modal type theory where the morphisms of my 2-category represent modalities, and some of the modalities are actually themselves named ♭\flat♭ and ♯\sharp♯, so that would be kind of confusing...
Yeah, that makes sense.

Seems like fLf^LfL is the only notation here that a reader can reliably guess the meaning of, at least once they know it's some adjoint to fff and maybe even before that. It's also a typographical generalization of $f^{-1},$ which seems good.

I do generally associate this notation with the situation where every morphism has a left and right adjoint (which I assume is not the case for these modalities), but I don't see why that necessarily has to be the case.

Mike Shulman said:

Another symbol that could be used for one or the other is f†f^\daggerf†. But I'm not sure which it would be, or what the other one would be. Maybe f§⊣f⊣f†f^\S \dashv f \dashv f^\daggerf§⊣f⊣f†?

Just as is sometimes done with left and right duals in a monoidal category, you could do †f⊣f⊣f†{}^\dagger f \dashv f \dashv f^\dagger†f⊣f⊣f†.
I haven't seen that for duals in a monoidal category, do you have a reference?

Mike Shulman said:

I haven't seen that for duals in a monoidal category, do you have a reference?

Being his ex masters student, I know that Cockett uses this sort of notation for duals in non-symmetric linearly distributive categories (probably lots of his colleaguess as well). For example:
https://www.math.mcgill.ca/rags/bicats/bicat.pdf

I would associate it with quantum group people, they talk of left duality and right duality. I would suspect it's used in Kassel's book, but I don't have it to hand here. Shahn Majid's books would be another place to look. The first thing I could find on googling was this:

https://vainerman.users.lmno.cnrs.fr/enseign/M2QG.pdf
To be clear: they don't do this with †\dagger†, but with ∗\ast∗.
Thanks. But it looks to me like the paper on linear bicategories uses f⊥f^\perpf⊥ (for the left adjoint) and ⊥f^\perp f⊥f (for the right adjoint)? (Page 14)

Mike Shulman said:

Thanks. But it looks to me like the paper on linear bicategories uses f⊥f^\perpf⊥ (for the left adjoint) and ⊥f^\perp f⊥f (for the right adjoint)? (Page 14)

Yes sorry for not being clear. I have never actually seen the dagger used, but I have seen the perp and star. edit: I didn't even notice that the adjoints were mixed up!
https://mathoverflow.net/a/351714

For the benefit of those who don't want to click on the link, someone asked this same question on MO three years ago, and was told that EGA writes adF⊣F⊣Fad^{\rm ad}F \dashv F \dashv F^{\rm ad}adF⊣F⊣Fad.
Thanks for the link! That looks kind of ugly to me though.

I think "ad" could well be replaced by some symbol like †\dagger† while preserving the good thing about this notation, namely that it's really easy to remember which is the left adjoint and which is the right adjoint.
Yes, I think †f⊣f⊣f†{}^\dagger f \dashv f \dashv f^\dagger†f⊣f⊣f† is the best suggestion I've seen so far.
What's the typical method of disambiguating f†ff^\dag ff†f with this notation? With ∘\circ∘?
I don't know what's typical, but in my case, yes, I would use ∘\circ∘.
